body: Does anyone have suggestions here? I’m trying to read docs on how to do this and not finding many answers. I’ll keep digging. We do have ‘[d]’ in the console_scripts entry ...
I'm fairly sure this used to work as described in the docs. Has something changed in or around `pip`?

From [the python packaging guide](https://python-packaging-user-guide.readthedocs.io/specifications/entry-points/?highlight=extras#file-format):

> Using extras for an entry point is no longer recommended. Consumers should support parsing them from existing distributions, but may then ignore them. New publishing tools need not support specifying extras. The functionality of handling extras was tied to setuptools’ model of managing ‘egg’ packages, but newer tools such as pip and virtualenv use a different model.

It's unclear to me what this different model is, but we should probably use that.
I did see this too, but I can't work out what it is. I'll call in favors from friends to try work this out.

That was added to the guide in https://github.com/pypa/packaging.python.org/pull/390.

I've not read through it, but it also adds an "entry points specification", perhaps there's something useful in there? Could also ask someone from that PR?

issue.title: Add tripplite prometheus exporter

repository.name: tripplite
repository.description: Python USB HID interface to Tripplite UPS battery backups.

issue.body:
- Add new triplite-exporter binary + tool
  - I've made the tool live with the import time cachine of `battery_paths`
- Today, we only support 1 UPS per Linux system
  - Would take a PR adding labels to each metric to support each - Probably hid.name
- This tool runs a small HTTP webserver and translates metrics to Prometheus Guages to be `scraped`
- This is an extra install so people who don't need the `prometheus_client` don't install it
- Also fixed some Markdown formatting / lints

Tested running on my Ubuntu 20.04 Linux home router that connects via USB to my Tripplite SMART1500LCD
- Python Version: Python 3.8.2
- Output: https://pastebin.com/JH0cLGLq

Known bug is the entry point (`tripplite-exporter`) will be installed on all installs. There apparently
is a new way to do this in a cleaner fashion (i.e. only install with extra install), and I'll eventually
work it out and come back with another PR. Will be doing for black too: https://github.com/psf/black/issues/1688

Fixes #5

issue.title: Add blackd to nicely exit if missing aiohttp deps
issue.body:
- If no aiohttp* deps exist nicely print a helpful message and exit
- There seems to be no nice way to optionally install the entry point, so lets make the entry point nicer

Test:
```
cooper-mbp1:black cooper$ /tmp/tb/bin/pip install .
cooper-mbp1:black cooper$ /tmp/tb/bin/blackd
aiohttp dependency is not installed: No module named 'aiohttp'. Please re-install black with the '[d]' extra install to obtain aiohttp_cors: `pip install black[d]`
cooper-mbp1:black cooper$ /tmp/tb/bin/pip install .[d]
...
Successfully installed aiohttp-3.6.3 aiohttp-cors-0.7.0 black
cooper-mbp1:black cooper$ /tmp/tb/bin/blackd
blackd version 20.8b2.dev31+gdd2f86a.d20201013 listening on localhost port 45484
```

Fixes #1688

issue.title: Change sys.exit to Raise.
issue.body:
The fix for #1688 in #1761 breaks `help("modules")` introspection and also leads to unhappy results when inadvertently importing `blackd` from python.  E.g.:

```
$ python
Python 3.8.10 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, May 11 2021, 07:01:05) 
[GCC 9.3.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> help('modules')

Please wait a moment while I gather a list of all available modules...

aiohttp dependency is not installed: No module named 'aiohttp'. Please re-install black with the '[d]' extra install to obtain aiohttp_cors: `pip install black[d]`
$
```
(Notice that python has been exited).

This PR changes the `sys.exit(-1)` in the `import` code to a proper `Raise`.
